METS:xmlData.entity:description: Petindvajset let od razpada Sovjetske zveze se Armenija in Azerbajdžan še vedno spoprijemata s spornimi mejami, ustvarjenimi v dvajsetih letih dvajsetega stoletja, in dediščino sovraštva in nasilja, ki je izšla iz tega. Na podlagi izvirnega raziskovalnega dela na terenu in nedavne štipendije na področju ustvarjanja mej in oblikovanja identitete v Sovjetski zvezi ta prispevek preučuje kompleksne temelje boljševiške ozemeljske delitve, povezavo med mejami in izoblikovanjem nacionalne identitete ter nenačrtovane posledice mej iz sovjetskega obdobja, ki so zanetile konflikte in še vedno vplivajo na geopolitično podobo Armenije in Azerbajdžana. Avtor želi v prispevku na primeru mesta Kirovabad (Gandža) – drugega največjega mesta v Azerbajdžanski sovjetski socialistični republiki, ki se nahaja v bližini avtonomne pokrajine Gorski Karabah – opisati izkušnjo in poznejši propad etničnega pluralizma na Južnem Kavkazu ter pojasniti, kako so dejanske in namišljene meje polarizirale Armence in Azerbajdžance v mračnih časih sovjetske oblasti, kar je pripeljalo do razbitja skupnosti in uničujoče vojne (1988–1994), ki še vedno traja. V desetletjih po smrti Stalina so meje sovjetskih republik postajale vedno bolj podobne orisom protonacionalnih držav, v katerih so narodi, po katerih so bile poimenovane, povzdigovali svojo nacionalno kulturo in pridobili privilegiran položaj, s čimer se je krepila predstava, da so sovjetske republike etnične domovine, ne pa večnacionalni talilni lonci. S tem se je v tako imenovani "drugi fazi" korenizacije ("nativizacije") postopno utrdil občutek nacionalne identitete in etnične različnosti med Armenci in Azerbajdžanci, kar je pozneje povzročilo izbruh množičnega nasilja in depopulacijo v obdobju glasnosti in perestrojke. Nenadni razcvet in obujanje fizičnih in mentalnih mej v tem napetem obdobju – od improviziranih obrambnih zaprek do vizij o pretekli ozemeljski veličini in prastarih predstav o "drugem" – sta spodkopala desetletja mirnega sožitja in ustvarila antagonistične nacionalistične naracije, ki so še danes trdno ukoreninjene.

Twenty-five years since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Armenia and Azerbaijan still grapple with contested borders forged during the 1920s and legacies of hatred and violence that have arisen from them. Drawing upon original fieldwork and recent scholarship on border making and identity formation in the Soviet Union, this paper examines the complex rationale behind the Bolsheviks’ territorial divisions, the link between borders and the crystallization of national identity, and the unintended consequences of Soviet-era borders that stoked conflict and continue to haunt today’s geopolitical landscape in Armenia and Azerbaijan. Using the city of Kirovabad (Ganja)—the second largest city in the Azerbaijani Soviet Socialist Republic located near the Nagorny Karabakh Autonomous Oblast’—as a window on the lived experience and subsequent demise of ethnic pluralism in the South Caucasus, this paper seeks to explain how both real and imagined borders polarized Armenians and Azeris in the twilight years of Soviet rule, leading to shattered communities and a devastating war (1988-1994) that persists to the present day. In the post-Stalin decades, the borders of Soviet republics increasingly resembled the contours of proto-nation-states in which titular nations celebrated their national cultures and acquired privileged positions, reinforcing the idea that Soviet republics were ethnic homelands rather than multinational melting pots. Thus, what one might call a “second phase” of korenizatsiia (“indigenization”) gradually instilled a more coherent sense of national identity, as well as ethnic difference, among Armenians and Azerbaijanis that would later erupt in mass violence and depopulation during the years of glasnost’ and perestroika. The sudden proliferation and resurrection of physical and mental borders—ranging from makeshift defensive barriers to visions of past territorial greatness to age-old images of the “other”—during this tense period unraveled decades of peaceful coexistence and produced antagonistic nationalist narratives that remain firmly entrenched today.
